description: Medium - Systemic Crisis and Political Consequences

questions.question: How did the patronage system (clientela) reinforce social inequality in Rome?
options: Wealthy patrons were legally required to provide aid regardless of client behavior or loyalty
The system guaranteed equal wealth distribution among all Romans over time
Poor clients remained dependent on patron support, giving wealthy elites control over voting blocs
Clients could accumulate wealth through patronage and eventually become independent farmers
Patronage created obligations that prevented wealthy patrons from accumulating more power
questions.text_reference: Section 5 - Dependency on Patrons and the Patronage System

questions.question: What did latifundia owners have in common with the wealthy families dominating the Senate?
options: They all owned latifundia and benefited from consolidated landholding and slave labor
They were all former military commanders seeking political power
They had all migrated from other Mediterranean regions to Rome
They were hostile to grain exports and wanted to keep prices high for consumers
They opposed the use of enslaved workers and preferred free labor
questions.text_reference: Section 4 - Why Latifundia Made Economic Sense

questions.question: Why was Rome's dependence on imported grain a source of political vulnerability? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Grain producers could manipulate prices and hold Rome hostage to their economic interests
Whoever controlled the grain trade controlled Rome's survival and had enormous political power
Grain imports enriched Rome's enemies and funded military forces against Rome
Foreign powers could disrupt supplies causing starvation and forcing Rome into unfavorable agreements
All of the above represent aspects of Rome's grain dependency vulnerability

questions.question: What was the relationship between land concentration and military recruitment in Rome? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome's armies traditionally depended on independent farmer-citizens with personal stakes in defending the state
As small farms disappeared, the military increasingly recruited poor men with no land or property
Landless soldiers had less incentive to defend a system that had dispossessed them
Military recruitment became easier as enslaved workers filled the ranks automatically
The shift undermined the traditional basis of Rome's military power
questions.text_reference: Section 7 - The Structural Problems Rome Couldn't Solve

questions.question: How did Cornelia influence her sons' political philosophy?
options: She taught them to defend Senate interests and oppose popular reform movements
She provided education in philosophy and rhetoric and convinced them the system was broken and reform was necessary
She encouraged them to accumulate personal wealth without concern for social problems
She insisted they follow traditional paths of aristocratic politics without challenging the system
She had no interest in politics and left their education entirely to male tutors

questions.question: What was the fundamental contradiction in Tiberius's proposal to stand for re-election as tribune?
options: The Senate supported re-election but the plebs opposed it
Tribune positions were traditionally one-year terms with no re-election to prevent concentration of power
Re-election would have violated religious laws governing the office
Tiberius lacked the political support necessary to win re-election
The proposal would have eliminated the need for a tribune entirely
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - Tiberius's Attempts to Consolidate Power and His Death

questions.question: What did the Senate's refusal to prosecute Scipio Nasica for murdering Tiberius reveal?
options: Roman justice system granted tribal leaders immunity from prosecution
The Senate prioritized power over law
Murder was not considered a serious crime in Roman society
Tribunes had no actual legal protections despite their sacred status
Scipio acted in legitimate self-defense against Tiberius's attack
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - The Violation of Sacred Law

questions.question: What economic and social reforms did Gaius Gracchus propose beyond land redistribution? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Abolition of the patronage system and direct government support for all citizens
Tax reforms that would redistribute wealth from wealthy to poor Romans
Grain law providing subsidized grain at controlled prices for the urban poor
Citizenship expansion to grant Italian allies voting rights and political participation
Judiciary reform reducing Senate control of courts and empowering equestrians
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - Gaius Gracchus: The Continuation of Reform

questions.question: Who were the equestrians (equites) and why did Gaius threaten Senate interests by empowering them?
options: They were cavalry soldiers who dominated military affairs and wanted political power
They were wealthy non-senatorial businessmen excluded from political power despite comparable wealth and education
They were former slaves who had earned freedom and sought political representation
They were merchant traders from Greek cities seeking to control Roman commerce
They were Italian allies seeking integration into Roman political structures
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - Gaius Gracchus: The Continuation of Reform

questions.question: What was the paradox of the Gracchi's ultimate failure?
options: They failed to implement any reforms and everything returned to pre-reform conditions
They succeeded in their goals but the Senate ignored their reforms anyway
They proved the system was working well by failing to gain popular support
Their reforms made Rome stronger and prevented future civil conflicts
They won individual reforms but lost their lives, yet exposed the Republic's fundamental fragility
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - The Aftermath: The System Breaks, But Survives for Now
